reason: The conclusion (total antisymmetry of q-3j with j1=j2=j3=j, j odd, under permutation of m-indices) is likely correct, but the justification has a gap: (1) The claim invokes 'quantum Regge symmetries' without citation or proof that the full 72-element Regge symmetry group extends to q-3j symbols. The full q-Regge symmetries are NOT established in the standard literature (Kirillov-Reshetikhin 1988, Groza-Kachurik-Klimyk 1990). (2) What IS established is the simpler column-permutation symmetry: odd permutation of columns of the q-3j symbol gives phase (-1)^{j1+j2+j3}, with no q-dependent correction. This follows from the q-analog of the van der Waerden formula. (3) Only this column-permutation symmetry (not full Regge symmetry) is needed for the antisymmetry claim. The proof should cite the specific q-3j column-permutation symmetry (e.g., Eq.(3.12) in Groza-Kachurik-Klimyk, J.Math.Phys.31(1990)2769) rather than the unsupported 'quantum Regge symmetries'.
